results.title: Lifestyle intervention is associated with lower prevalence of urinary incontinence: the Diabetes Prevention Program.
results.text_hl: This difference was most apparent among @SPECIES_9606 @@@women@@@ with @<m>DISEASE_Urinary_Incontinence_Stress</m> @DISEASE_MESH:D014550 @@@stress incontinence@@@ (31.3% for intensive lifestyle group vs. 39.7% for @<m>CHEMICAL_Metformin</m> @CHEMICAL_MESH:D008687 @@@metformin@@@ vs. 36.7% for placebo, P = 0.006).

citations.NLM: Brown JS, Wing R, Barrett-Connor E, Nyberg LM, Kusek JW, Orchard TJ, Ma Y, Vittinghoff E, Kanaya AM, Diabetes Prevention Program Research Group. Lifestyle intervention is associated with lower prevalence of urinary incontinence: the Diabetes Prevention Program. Diabetes Care. 2006 Feb;29(2):385-90. PMID: 16443892
